awd_titl_txt: Quantifying the Thermo-Mechanical Response and Strain-Rate Effects in Magnesium Microcrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT:

This project will focus on quantifying the deformation mechanisms that dominate at elevated temperatures and different deformation rates in magnesium (Mg) and its alloys. One approach to reduce carbon dioxide emission from fossil-fuel powered vehicles is to increase their fuel efficiency by reducing the vehicle structural weight. To that end, Mg alloys demonstrate a favorable strength-to-weight ratio and provide valid alternatives to aluminum alloys and high strength steels. Thus, there is a growing interest in utilizing Mg alloys in many automotive, aerospace and defense applications. However, at present, one of the limiting factors for the wide production and use of Mg alloys is their low formability at room temperature, which leads to many technological and economical constraints. This is mainly due to the low ductility of Mg alloys at room temperature. As such, most Mg sheets are formed at elevated temperatures below their recrystallization limit (~400ºC). Another challenge is the high strain-rate sensitivity of Mg, which necessitates low speed forming processes. This award will thus supports research to fundamentally identify the deformation mechanisms through a set of state-of-the-art multi-length scale experimental and simulation techniques. The results of this project are expected to assist in the process of developing new Mg alloys that demonstrate improved formability and enhanced ductility and toughness at a wider range of temperatures and strain rates. The integration of research, education and outreach in this project will also: (1) improve STEM achievement in a predominately African American elementary school in Baltimore, currently ranked below 92% of schools in Maryland; (2) involve under-represented students from a local historically black college through internships on research in mechanics and materials; and (3) develop an education portfolio that intensifies the knowledge of undergraduate and graduate students in fundamentals of state-of-the-art multiscale modeling and micro-scale experiments.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT:

The primary research objectives of this research are to fundamentally identify the coupled strain rate effect and thermo-mechanical response of Mg and AZ31 microcrystals (fabricated in bulk single crystals) through coupled novel in situ scanning electron microscopy elevated-temperature experiments, and novel large scale three-dimensional discrete dislocation dynamics simulations that account for dislocation-twin boundary interactions. The research hinges around addressing four challenging objectives: (1) Quantify the thermo-mechanical properties and deformation mechanisms in the range of 30 to 400ºC in Mg and AZ31 microcrystals; (2) Identify the origins of the anomalous hardening response observed at 30% of the melting temperature of Mg; (3) Quantify the strain rate effects at different temperatures on the deformation mechanisms in the range of 1e-4 to 0.1 s; and (4)  Generate a four dimensional model of the correlation between temperature, strain rate, crystal size, and strength.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Magnesium (Mg) and its alloys are very promising for a wide range of structural applications, in the automotive, aerospace, electronics, and biomedical industries, due to their lightweight. However, the highly anisotropic plasticity of the hexagonal-close packed (HCP) lattice structure leads to low formability, which makes the plastic working of Mg and Mg alloys very difficult. One of the main reasons limiting the current use of Mg and its alloys in many applications, is the need to improve their strength and creep resistance at elevated temperatures. Nevertheless, there are few studies on Mg and its alloys at elevated temperatures as compared to other metals, and those that do exist provide many puzzling observations.

The primary objectives of this work were to fundamentally characterize the deformation of Mg and its alloys as a function of temperatures. This was achieved through a combination of experimental studies (traditional high temperature bulk compression studies as well as in situ scanning electron microscopy experiments), computational modeling (large-scale three-dimensional molecular dynamics and discrete dislocation dynamics simulations), and theoretical modeling. We have utilized our computational modeling to characterize the strain-rate and dislocation density dependence of the strength of bulk single crystals [1].  In the following we list some of the highlights of the outcomes of this research. Our combined experiments and simulations have led to the development of a deformation mechanism map as a function of crystal size for twin-oriented Mg single crystals, ranging from the nano-scale to bulk-scale [2-5]. Based on these experiments we were able to quantify that the anomalous hardening observed in extension twin oriented Mg single crystals at 20 mm is induced by a size-dependent transition in deformation modes from a single twin dominant response to twin-twin and dislocation-twin interactions dominant response [2]. A transition in deformation mode was also observed for a given crystal size with increasing temperature, with an anomalous increase in the flow stress at the critical temperature at which this transition occurs [3]. This was attributed to the paucity of dislocation sources that are required to promote twin boundary migration. This critical temperature is also size-dependent. A transition in deformation mode was also observed in textured Mg polycrystals, with the complete suppression of twinning with increasing temperature [4].

Our simulations have also addressed open questions on the characteristics of dislocation slip on pyramidal-planes in Mg and the mechanisms that lead to the lack of ductility in Mg at room temperature and the anomalous thermal-hardening observed experimentally during c-axis compression [6-9]. Our results show a sharply anisotropic response for the critical resolved shear with pyramidal dislocation orientations, which indicates a much complex picture of plasticity in Mg than previously thought. Pyramidal dislocations show a strong plastic anisotropic behavior and the second-order pyramidal slip is limited by two singular mixed dislocation orientations at, which explains many of the complex dislocation networks commonly observed experimentally after deformation. Finally, our theoretical modeling also proposed a formation mechanism of pyramidal dislocations in the twins from the TB [10].

This fundamental research provides an original understanding of the mechanisms associated with the deformation of both single crystal microcrystals and textured polycrystalline magnesium as a function of temperatures and strain rates. The research findings can assist in the development of new Mg alloys that demonstrate improved formability and enhanced ductility and toughness at a wider range of temperatures and strain rates, which subsequently can lead to increased utilization of Mg as a structural material in many industries (automotive, aerospace, bio-medical, etc.). This research was also integrated with outreach and education activities including: (1) provide mentoring and expertise to participating elementary school students, from under-representative minorities in the Baltimore Elementary Public School system, as they work on after-school STEM related projects; 2) hosting interns from ``Morgan State University'', a historically black collage in Baltimore; and 3) establish a new curriculum on Mesoscale Simulations of Defects in Metals of thermally activated mechanisms in solids. This project has resulted in 10 journal articles and 7 conference presentations. Two PhD students and two postdoctoral fellows were also involved in different aspects of the research.

References:

[1]       Fan et al., arXiv:2003.09560, (2020).
[2]       Sim et al., Acta Materialia, 144:11(2018).
[3]       Sim et al., Acta Materialia, 178:241(2019).
[4]       Plamthottam et al., MRS Communications, 9:1093(2019).
[5]       Ma et al., Acta Materialia, 189:35(2020).
[6]       Fan et al., Scripta Materialia, 135:37(2017).
[7]       Srivastava and El-Awady, Magnesium Technology, 305(2019) .
[8]       Srivastave and El-Awady, Acta Materialia, 133:282(2017).
[9]       Srivastave et al., Acta Materialia, 161:182(2018).
[10]     Wang et al., Acta Materialia, 195:13(2020).

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2021
Modified by: Jaafar El-Awady
